6 \section hardware-and-middleware Hardware and Middleware
7 
8 One of the most efficient ways to reduce the latency is to use specialized network cards (e.g.,
9 [Solarflare](https://www.solarflare.com)),
10 and user-space TCP stack implementations (e.g., [Onload](https://www.openonload.org/)).
11 
12 \see \ref understanding-send-latency
13 \see \ref solarflare-specific-features
14 
15 \section selecting-session-storage Selecting Session Storage
16 Using OnixS::B3::BOE::SessionStorageType::MemoryBased instead of OnixS::B3::BOE::SessionStorageType::FileBased boosts
17 performance, since SBE messages are stored directly in memory.
18 
19 Alternatively, it's possible to use pluggable storage ( OnixS::B3::BOE::SessionStorageType::Pluggable ) that does
20 nothing on message-related operations.
21 
22 You can also use the \ref asynchronous-file-based-session-storage if you need to keep the file-based storage
23 functionality and excellent performance.
24 
25 \section threads-tuning Threads Tuning
26 
27 \subsection affinity Affinity
28 By default, \ref threading-models "session threads" can be executed on any of the available processors/cores.
29 Specifying CPU affinity for each thread may give a significant performance boost:
30 \snippet LowLatencyBestPractices.cpp affinity
31 
32 \note Ideally, each spinning thread should run on a separate CPU core so that it will not stop other important threads
33 from doing work if it blocks or is de-scheduled.
34 \note If more than one spinning thread shares the same CPU core, it could significantly increase jitter.
35 
36 \subsection priority Priority
37 
38 To modify threads prioritis, use the OnixS::B3::BOE::Threading::ThisThread::priority,
39 OnixS::B3::BOE::Session::receivingThreadPriority, and OnixS::B3::BOE::Session::sendingThreadPriority methods.
40 
41 \subsection scheduling-policy Scheduling Policy
42 
43 To modify threads scheduling policies, use the OnixS::B3::BOE::Threading::ThisThread::policy,
44 OnixS::B3::BOE::Session::receivingThreadPolicy, and OnixS::B3::BOE::Session::sendingThreadPolicy methods.
45 
46 \note These methods are supported on Linux only.
47 \note `SCHED_FIFO` and `SCHED_RR` scheduling policies implement the fixed-priority real-time scheduling, so threads with
48 these policies preempt every other thread, which can go into starvation.
49 
50 \section spinning Spinning (busy-wait)
51 
52 \note The user-space TCP stack spinning is usually more efficient than the built-in spinning (e.g.,
53 [Onload's](https://www.openonload.org/) `EF_POLL_USEC` environment variable or the `latency-best` profile).
54 
55 \subsection receive-spinning-timeout Receive Spinning Timeout
56 
57 When a session receiving thread attempts to read from a network and no incoming messages are available, the thread will
58 enter the OS kernel and block (so-called "blocking wait" mode).
59 When an incoming message becomes available, the network adapter will interrupt the CPU, allowing the OS kernel to
60 reschedule the thread to continue.
61 
62 Blocking, interrupts, and thread context switches are relatively expensive operations and can negatively affect the
63 latency.
64 
65 The session can be configured to spin on the processor in user mode for up to a specified number of microseconds waiting
66 for messages from the network using the OnixS::B3::BOE::Session::receiveSpinningTimeout method.
67 If the spin period expires, the session will revert to normal blocking behavior.
68 
69 OnixS::B3::BOE::Session::receiveSpinningTimeout usage makes sense when the session receives SBE messages frequently, in
70 this case, waiting in the loop is cheaper than the thread context switch to the "blocking wait" mode.
71 
72 \note The spin wait increases the CPU usage, so the spin wait period should not be too long.
73 
74 \subsection send-spinning-timeout Send Spinning Timeout
75 
76 The OnixS::B3::BOE::Session::sendSpinningTimeout method can be used to decrease the latency of the message sending.
77 
78 If the value is zero (by default) and the outgoing message cannot be sent immediately, it is saved to the outgoing queue.
79 If the value greater than zero, the OnixS::B3::BOE::Session::send method waits for the socket sending buffer availability
80 in the spin loop mode before placing the message to the outgoing queue (to be sent later by the sending thread).
81 
82 OnixS::B3::BOE::Session::sendSpinningTimeout usage makes sense when the session sends SBE messages frequently, in this
83 case, waiting in the loop is cheaper than the thread context switch.
84 
85 \note The spin wait increases the CPU usage, so the spin wait period should not be too long.
86 
87 \section session-warmup Warmup
88 
89 If the session sends SBE messages infrequently, the sending path and associated data structures will not be in a cache,
90 and this can increase the message sending latency.
91 
92 One can periodically (a recommended interval is `500` microseconds or less) call the OnixS::B3::BOE::Session::warmUp
93 to avoid cache misses and keep the sending path fast.
94 
95 \section using-session-send-batch Using session send batch
96 
97 The OnixS::B3::BOE::Session::send method can be used to send messages in a batch. It can decrease the send latency
98 because all batch messages
99 will be sent in one TCP packet.
100 The OnixS::B3::BOE::Messaging::MessageBatch class represents the message batch.
101 This class instance should be created in advance on the non-critical path, and required messages should be added. After
102 that, one can send the batch on the critical path:
103 
104 \snippet LowLatencyBestPractices.cpp batchSend
105 
106 Also, there is the OnixS::B3::BOE::Messaging::MessageBatchCombiner class, which can be used when one needs to send
107 messages with different types in the batch.
108 It can combine different OnixS::B3::BOE::Messaging::MessageBatch or OnixS::B3::BOE::Messaging::MessageHolder instances.
109 \warning It does not copy combined messages and does not store them internally.
110 Therefore, the lifetime of combined messages should be greater or equal to the lifetime of this class instance:
111 
112 \snippet LowLatencyBestPractices.cpp messageBatchCombiner
113 
114 \note The OnixS::B3::BOE::Session::messageGrouping setting conflicts with the usage of the session send batch and can
115 affect it.
116 For the batch sending, the session uses the "gathering" socket `send` system call, which accepts an array of buffers to
117 send all of them at once.
118 When one sets the OnixS::B3::BOE::Session::messageGrouping setting, the session tries to combine (copy) outgoing
119 messages (when available) to the one outgoing buffer
120 until the given grouping value is achieved and then uses the regular socket `send` system call for sending.
121 Therefore, one should not use the OnixS::B3::BOE::Session::messageGrouping option and batch sending simultaneously.
122 
123 \section logging-after-sending Logging After Sending
124 By default, the logging of an outgoing message to the session storage is performed before sending it to the wire.
125 This approach is more reliable because the outgoing message is stored before going to the counterparty.
126 However, this approach adds the logging latency to the message sending latency, so it increases the tick-to-trade
127 latency.
128 
129 When the latency is more important, one can switch off the logging before sending, by setting the
130 OnixS::B3::BOE::Session::logBeforeSending option to `false`.
131 In this case, the logging of outgoing messages to the session storage will be performed after sending them to the wire.
132 
133 \section reusing-sbe-message-instance Reusing Message Instances
134 
135 A common strategy is to use the same outgoing application-level message instance multiple times.
136 
137 
138 \section sending-time Sending time
139 
140 The BOE protocol requires the `timestamp` field to be filled with "the number of nanoseconds since Unix epoch" for each
141 outgoing message.
142 This is done automatically by the session when OnixS::B3::BOE::Session::send is invoked.
143 
144 The current time value is provided as an argument of OnixS::B3::BOE::Session::send; this argument has the default value
145 of the current system time being calculated at the invocation time.
146 
147 The latency of taking system time can be avoided if it is requested before the call is made, for instance, at the
148 warm-up stage.
149 Also, when the session is used with the OnixS C++ B3 Market Data Handler, this value can be taken from the network
150 packet receiving time.
